results.title: Persuasion [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Roger Michell, Fiona Finlay, BBC, Millesime Productions, Mobil Masterpiece Theatre and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description: Originally made as a telemovie but released in cinemas, “Persuasion” is an adaptation of Jane Austen’s last novel about love lost and regained. Amanda Root gives a sensitive performance as Ann Eliot, while Ciaran Hinds is Captain Frederick Wentworth. Eight years prior to the opening of the story, Ann and Wentworth were in love but Ann is persuaded by her family and friend Lady Russell, to abandon the then penniless Wentworth. Time does not alter the depth of her love for him and she is resigned to solitude. Circumstances reunite the couple and this time it is her family who are impecunious and Wentworth who is rich. Can he put aside the bitterness of her rejection and rekindle the flame of their affection?
results.creator_credit_for_label: Roger Michell, Fiona Finlay, BBC, Millesime Productions, Mobil Masterpiece Theatre and WGBH (Boston)

results.title: Persuasion
results.brief_description: Despite knowing her own heart, Anne Elliot allows herself to be “persuaded” into rejecting the proposal of Captain Wentworth. After an eight year separation, they meet again. Although still eligible and now prosperous, Wentworth is still bitter and courts the attention of Louisa Musgrove. As is typical of all Austen novels, as Anne and Wentworth undertake the road to matrimony, a small section of a long ago society, with its social mores is exposed. Adapted by Julian Mitchell, this BBC production has the flavour of authenticity and features Ann Firbank and Bryan Marshall as the two lovers.

results.title: Perspectrum = Perspectre
results.creator_credit: Ishu Patel, Dorothy Courtois and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An animated film of simple geometric forms, as thin and flat as playing cards, but so arranged that a sense of perspective is conveyed. The effect is somewhat like the patterns seen in a kaleidoscope, but much more active, forming and re-forming constantly to the music. The koto, a thirteen-stringed Japanese instrument, is played by plucking the strings; the sound has a tinkling effect, well-suited to the glasslike shapes of the moving designs. A film without words.

results.title: Perspective: student nurse
results.creator_credit: Donald Ginsberg, Donald Bairstow and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A picture of nurses-in-training at a large city hospital in Montreal. The starched blue uniforms of the probationers barely conceal the nervousness with which they approach their new vocation, but apparent above all is the earnest desire to learn and to do what the profession demands. The film also shows some of the courses the nurses take before they are qualified to receive their caps.

results.title: Persistent and finagling
results.creator_credit: Michael Rubbo, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The growing resolve of a group of Montreal women, members of STOP (Society To Overcome Pollution), to do something about air pollution by factories in their city led to a campaign to focus public attention on the problem. Despite rebuffs of every kind, they persisted until they were able to bring newspapers, radio and television to bear on their fight. What they accomplished, and how they went about it, will interest urban audiences.

results.title: Dreamland: a history of early Canadian movies 1895-1939
results.creator_credit: Kirwan Cox, Donald Brittain and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: People have become so sated with spectacular inventions and achievements that it is now difficult to imagine the sensation created by the first motion picture films, in which people actually moved about on the screen just as in real life. Little is left of those early days of Canadian cinema. But from the footage available, the filmmakers have pieced together an absorbing account of what went on the screens of the nation in those times, and of the people who influenced the fledgling industry. This is a flashback to the past that all will enjoy.

results.title: Dreamings : the art of Aboriginal Australia
results.creator_credit: Michael Riley, Janet Bell and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Dreamings is a journey into the lush mangroves and scarred heartlands of Australia to see traditional aboriginal artists at work. From the air we view some of the landforms and waterways incorporated in the imagery of paintings by Michael Nelson Jakamarra. He talks of his family’s association with the land and his intrinsic faith in spiritual connections with animals and plants. Our voyage continues to the Great Western Desert and a sacred waterhole. This program begins to unravel some of the mysteries behind creations of immense artistic beauty.

results.title: Dress for Success
results.brief_description: Each year the final students at Sydney’s design colleges compete for a fashion design award. In 1991 the theme was for an evening dress which reflected the multicultural heritage of Australia. The judges, students and teachers comment on the designs themselves, the state of the fashion industry in Australia and their own personal hopes and dreams.

results.title: Dreamlives [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Jennifer Crone and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Partners in life and art, Sydney photographers Narelle Autio and Trent Park discuss why they are drawn to one another’s work and what inspires and motivates them when they are behind the lens. Cameras follow the pair as they photograph goat racing in Lightning Ridge and attempt to capture the essence of Sydney city. They talk of work on their first collaboration in 2001 - the Seventh wave - which depicted images of Australian beach life and garnered them the World Press Award. They also speak of the moniker of “The Roo couple,” coined for their surrealistic images of dead animals by the roadside.
